content:
Pendle Borough Council's spending data reveals unusual patterns that warrant scrutiny — from a single supplier generating over 5,000 transactions to mysterious multi-million pound payments to other councils, and a year-end spending surge worth £1.7 million above normal.

FUELMATE LTD: 5,047 Transactions Totalling £800,200

The council's most frequent supplier by a wide margin is Fuelmate Ltd, a fuel card provider. With 5,047 transactions averaging just £159 each, this represents roughly 10% of all council transactions by volume. While fuel cards generate individual transaction records for each fill-up, the sheer volume raises questions:

  • How many vehicles does the council operate that require 5,047 fuel transactions?
  • Could the council negotiate bulk fuel purchasing instead of individual card transactions?
  • Is there adequate oversight of fuel card usage to prevent personal use?

£20.1 Million in Round-Number Payments

We flagged 774 payments over £5,000 that are exact round numbers, totalling £20.1 million. Round-number payments can indicate:

  • Estimates rather than actual costs — genuine invoices rarely come to exactly £10,000 or £50,000
  • Budget transfers — moving money between accounts or departments
  • Grants or contributions — which may be round figures by design
  • Advance payments — paying an estimated amount before final costs are known

While not all round-number payments are problematic, the pattern is worth monitoring. Best practice is for councils to pay against actual invoices, not estimates.

The Cross-Authority Transfers

Two payments stand out for their size and unusual destination:

Recipient Amount Question
Brentwood Borough Council£3,000,000Why is a Lancashire council paying £3M to an Essex council?
Surrey County Council£3,000,000What service requires a £3M payment to a council 250 miles away?

Cross-authority payments of this size are unusual for a district council with a total spend of £127 million. These two payments alone represent nearly 5% of all spending. Possible explanations include pooled investment schemes, pension fund transfers, or shared service arrangements — but the council should explain what these payments are for.

Year-End Spending Surge: Financial Services

Pendle's Financial Services department spent 2.7 times its monthly average in March, representing £1.7 million above normal. While less extreme than Hyndburn's 12.9x spike, it still indicates budget-clearing behaviour at year-end.

PendleFinancial Services2.7x

What This Tells Us

Pendle's spending patterns are characterised by high volume and low value — the opposite of Burnley, which has fewer but larger transactions. This creates different risks: less individual scrutiny per transaction, higher processing costs, and more opportunities for small errors to accumulate. The council should consider whether consolidating small payments could improve efficiency and oversight.

All figures derived from publicly available Pendle Borough Council spending data published under the Local Government Transparency Code.
